or educational organizations. (Appendix B also indicates

Attempts to classify and categorize the projects in
progress suffered mainly from an insufficient supply of
information, although the questionnaire requested, where
appropriate, such ‘data as hypotheses being tested, independ¬
ent and dependent variables, size and type of sample popula¬
tions, measuring instruments employed and statistical tests
applied.
Seven categories were decided upon, based on areas and
kinds of research which the respondents reported. (See
Table 4.)
TABLE 4

IN PROGRESS
NO.
of Projects
1. Surveys, analyses and compilations 22
2. Experience with and utilization of methods,
techniques and materials 19
3. Experimental studies in achievement and
the effectiveness of instruction 22
4. Studies of attitudes, interest factors, and
motivations of teachers, students and
administrators 12
5. Audience effects 14
6. Measurement and methods of testing 3
7. Administrative personnel and practices 4
